Bacterial_blight.summary: Bacterial blight is a serious rice disease caused by Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae. It can cause significant yield loss, especially in irrigated and rain-fed lowland areas.
Bacterial_blight.cause: Caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae. Spreads through infected seeds, crop residues, and contaminated water. Favored by high humidity, rain, and wind.
Bacterial_blight.symptoms: Water-soaked streaks on leaf blades that turn yellow to gray; leaves may wilt and dry (kresek). Lesions often start at leaf tips or edges. In severe cases, entire leaves die.
Bacterial_blight.spread: Transmitted via infected seed, wind-blown rain, irrigation water, and mechanical contact. Bacteria enter through wounds or natural openings. Survives in crop residues and alternate hosts.
Bacterial_blight.treatment: Remove and destroy severely infected plants. Apply approved copper-based bactericides early; repeat as needed. Ensure balanced nitrogen; avoid excess. Flood fallow or rotate to reduce inoculum.
Bacterial_blight.prevention: Use certified disease-free seed. Choose resistant or tolerant varieties. Avoid overhead irrigation when possible. Practice field sanitation and destroy crop residues. Maintain proper plant spacing and avoid excess nitrogen.

Blast.summary: Rice blast is a fungal disease caused by Pyricularia oryzae. It affects leaves, nodes, panicles, and grains, and can cause severe yield loss under favorable conditions.
Blast.cause: Caused by the fungus Pyricularia oryzae (Magnaporthe oryzae). Develops in humid, warm conditions. Spores spread by wind and rain. Favored by prolonged leaf wetness and high nitrogen.
Blast.symptoms: Diamond-shaped or spindle-shaped lesions on leaves with gray centers and brown margins. Node and neck blast cause blackening and breakage. Panicle blast leads to empty or discolored grains.
Blast.spread: Wind and rain disperse spores. Overwinters on infected straw, seeds, and weeds. Spreads rapidly in dense crops and under high humidity and moderate temperatures (25–28°C).
Blast.treatment: Apply recommended fungicides (e.g., tricyclazole, isoprothiolane) at first sign of leaf blast; repeat for neck blast if needed. Reduce nitrogen. Improve drainage and avoid water stress.
Blast.prevention: Use resistant varieties. Use clean seed. Avoid excess nitrogen and late nitrogen application. Ensure good drainage. Destroy infected straw. Rotate crops where feasible.

Brown_spot.summary: Brown spot is a fungal disease of rice caused by Bipolaris oryzae. It reduces yield and grain quality, especially in nutrient-deficient or stressed plants.
Brown_spot.cause: Caused by the fungus Bipolaris oryzae (Cochliobolus miyabeanus). More severe in soils deficient in silicon, potassium, or manganese, and in water-stressed or weak plants.
Brown_spot.symptoms: Small, oval to circular brown spots on leaves, often with a yellow halo. Spots may coalesce. On grains, dark brown to black discoloration (black point). Seedlings may show collar rot.
Brown_spot.spread: Survives on infected seed and crop residues. Spores spread by wind and rain. Favored by high humidity, warm weather, and nutrient deficiency. Seed-borne transmission is common.
Brown_spot.treatment: Apply recommended fungicides if outbreak occurs early. Correct nutrient deficiencies (silicon, K, Mn). Improve water management. Remove severely infected plants to reduce spread.
Brown_spot.prevention: Use clean, treated seed. Maintain soil fertility (especially silicon and potassium). Choose less susceptible varieties. Practice crop rotation and residue management. Avoid water stress.

Tungro.summary: Rice tungro is a viral disease caused by Rice tungro bacilliform virus (RTBV) and Rice tungro spherical virus (RTSV), transmitted by green leafhoppers. It causes stunting and yield loss.
Tungro.cause: Caused by RTBV and RTSV, transmitted by green leafhoppers (Nephotettix spp.). Both viruses together cause severe symptoms. Insects acquire virus by feeding on infected plants.
Tungro.symptoms: Stunted, yellow-orange discolored plants; leaves may be mottled or striped. Reduced tillering and panicle size. Plants often appear in patches where leafhoppers have fed.
Tungro.spread: Spread by green leafhoppers (Nephotettix virescens and related species). No mechanical or seed transmission. Insects move from infected to healthy plants. Weeds can host viruses and vectors.
Tungro.treatment: No curative treatment for infected plants. Remove symptomatic plants to reduce virus source. Control leafhopper vectors with approved insecticides if populations are high and disease is spreading.
Tungro.prevention: Use resistant or tolerant varieties. Synchronize planting to avoid prolonged green bridge. Remove weeds and ratoon rice. Monitor leafhopper populations. Avoid planting near infected fields.

cercospora_leaf_spot.symptoms: Leaves show gray, rectangular lesions that are usually bounded by veins. Spots can expand and merge, leading to larger blighted areas and reduced leaf function. Symptoms are often more obvious on lower to mid-canopy leaves.
cercospora_leaf_spot.causes: This disease is caused by Cercospora fungi. It develops best in warm, humid conditions with frequent dew or leaf wetness. Infected crop residue can carry the fungus between seasons.
cercospora_leaf_spot.treatment: When disease pressure is high, apply a labeled fungicide at the recommended growth stage. Remove or manage heavily infected residue and avoid practices that keep leaves wet for long periods. Promote airflow by avoiding overly dense stands.
cercospora_leaf_spot.prevention: Plant resistant or tolerant hybrids when available. Rotate crops and manage residue to reduce overwintering inoculum. Use balanced fertility and irrigation practices to keep plants vigorous.
cercospora_leaf_spot.confidence_note: Field symptoms strongly suggest Cercospora leaf spot, but confirm with local extension guidance if lesions look unusual or mixed.

common_rust.symptoms: Small, round to elongated reddish-brown pustules appear on both leaf surfaces. Pustules may darken as they age and can be surrounded by yellow halos. Heavy infections can reduce photosynthesis and weaken plants.
common_rust.causes: Common rust is caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi. Spores are spread by wind and can travel long distances. Warm, humid weather favors rapid infection and spread.
common_rust.treatment: Fungicides can reduce severity when applied early and according to label directions. Focus on protecting the upper leaves that contribute most to grain fill. Scout regularly to time applications effectively.
common_rust.prevention: Use rust-resistant hybrids where possible. Avoid very late planting that exposes crops to peak rust pressure. Maintain good field hygiene and monitor regional rust reports.
common_rust.confidence_note: The rust-like pustules match common rust, but other rust diseases can look similar in certain regions.

healthy.symptoms: Leaves are uniformly green with no spots, streaks, or blighted areas. The leaf surface is smooth and firm, and the plant shows steady growth. No wilting or premature yellowing is present.
healthy.causes: Healthy plants result from good seed quality, balanced nutrition, and favorable growing conditions. Proper water management and low disease pressure help maintain leaf health. Early vigor is supported by consistent stand establishment.
healthy.treatment: No treatment is needed for healthy leaves. Continue routine scouting to catch any early signs of stress or disease. Maintain normal crop management practices.
healthy.prevention: Keep plants healthy with balanced fertilization, timely irrigation, and good weed control. Use clean seed and avoid plant stress from compaction or poor drainage. Rotate crops and manage residue to reduce future disease risk.
healthy.confidence_note: Leaf appearance indicates a healthy crop, but continue monitoring as conditions change.

northern_leaf_blight.symptoms: Long, cigar-shaped gray-green lesions develop on leaves and can turn tan as they age. Lesions may expand and coalesce, causing large areas of leaf blight. Upper leaves are especially important to protect during grain fill.
northern_leaf_blight.causes: Northern leaf blight is caused by the fungus Exserohilum turcicum. The pathogen survives on corn residue and spreads by wind and rain splash. Cool to moderate temperatures with high humidity favor infection.
northern_leaf_blight.treatment: Apply a labeled fungicide when lesions are first observed on susceptible hybrids and conditions favor spread. Prioritize protecting the ear leaf and leaves above it. Remove heavy residue where practical to reduce inoculum.
northern_leaf_blight.prevention: Plant hybrids with resistance or tolerance to northern leaf blight. Rotate crops and manage residue to lower disease carryover. Avoid excessive irrigation that keeps foliage wet for long periods.
northern_leaf_blight.confidence_note: Lesion shape and pattern are consistent with northern leaf blight; confirm locally if symptoms differ.

black_rust.summary: Black rust (also called stem rust) is a fungal disease of wheat that can cause severe yield losses under favorable conditions.
black_rust.cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia graminis. It spreads via wind-borne spores and is favored by warm, humid conditions and susceptible varieties.
black_rust.symptoms: Reddish-brown to black pustules on stems, leaves, and awns. Severely infected stems may weaken and lodge; infected heads can produce shriveled grain.
black_rust.spread: Spores travel long distances on wind. Inoculum survives on alternate hosts and crop residues. Epidemics arise when weather favors spore germination and infection.
black_rust.treatment: Remove and destroy volunteer wheat and alternate hosts where practical. Apply recommended fungicides early in the disease cycle following local guidance.
black_rust.prevention: Use resistant varieties where available, rotate crops, practice good field sanitation, and monitor regional advisories to time fungicide applications.

brown_rust.summary: Brown rust (leaf rust) is a common fungal disease of wheat that reduces photosynthetic area and yield when severe.
brown_rust.cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia triticina. It develops under warm, humid weather and spreads via wind-dispersed spores.
brown_rust.symptoms: Small, round to oval orange-brown pustules on leaf surfaces that release powdery spores. Infected leaves may yellow and die prematurely.
brown_rust.spread: Wind-borne spores spread rapidly between fields and regions. Overwinters on volunteer wheat and crop residues in some climates.
brown_rust.treatment: Apply labeled fungicides when economic thresholds are met and weather favors disease development. Follow local extension recommendations.
brown_rust.prevention: Plant resistant varieties, remove volunteer wheat and grasses, rotate crops, and monitor disease forecasts to time interventions appropriately.

healthy.summary: Healthy: no disease symptoms detected; normal growth and development.
healthy.symptoms: No visible lesions, discolouration, or abnormal growth. Leaves are green and turgid; heads and grains develop normally.
healthy.treatment: No treatment required. Maintain good agronomic practices to keep crop healthy.
healthy.prevention: Use proper nutrition, irrigation, and pest management; select adapted varieties and monitor regularly for early signs of stress or disease.

yellow_rust.summary: Yellow rust (stripe rust) is a damaging wheat disease that can spread quickly under cool, moist conditions.
yellow_rust.cause: Caused by the fungus Puccinia striiformis. Favors cool temperatures (10–20°C) with moisture; spreads via wind-borne spores.
yellow_rust.symptoms: Yellow to orange stripes or pustules along leaf veins. Severely infected plants have reduced tillering and grain filling leading to yield loss.
yellow_rust.spread: Wind dispersal of spores enables rapid long-distance spread. Overwinters on volunteer cereals and alternative hosts in some regions.
yellow_rust.treatment: Use registered fungicides when needed and follow integrated pest management recommendations. Timing of applications is critical for control.
yellow_rust.prevention: Grow resistant cultivars, monitor weather and disease forecasts, remove volunteer hosts, and use crop rotation where possible.
